item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Prostitution is a service, just like window cleaning is. Both branches can be criminalized. And just like any other service branche, you need an organisation that makes sure that both consumers and the providers of the service are protected.

@Mr. Chris: If women are forced into prostitution because they can’t fulfill their needs, it’s the fault of another system, not the fault of prostitution. I don’t have any numbers to back this up, but I have a strong feeling the prostitutes in the Netherlands are either forced to do it by traffickers or they do it because they enjoy it (or the money). We have proper health care, the poor get help, so there’s no need for a Dutch woman to sell her body in order to feed her children or pay bills. So in order to get rid of the women that are prostitutes because they are forced by traffickers, you need an organisation that comes up with rules, and enforces them.

item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:26, topic:399317”]Well I know this just from sort of general knowledge around London. I’ve also watched a lot of UK/US police shows and theres a pretty big correlation between drugs, need for money, and prostitution. A few minutes of searching and I discovered these stats. Also, I’m aware that the way prostitutes operate from country to country is always going to differ according to laws laid down.

we interviewed 237 prostitutes in the community and 407 comparison women at an STD clinic. Drug use was more commonly reported by prostitutes than comparisons (86% vs. 23%), as was non-consensual prepubertal sex (32% vs. 13%). Sexual- and drug-related milestones occurred in the same order in both groups, with drug use preceding sexual activity and injecting drug use preceding prostitution. Ninety-four percent of prostitutes who injected drugs reported noninjectable drug use before prostitution, and 75% of prostitutes who injected drugs reported doing so before beginning prostitution.

This survey was taken in the US.

As syphilis rates rose, there were large increases in the percentage of women with syphilis who reported prostitution or illicit drug use. In 1988, 41% of women with syphilis reported cocaine use, and 19% reported prostitution; 21% of male heterosexuals with syphilis reported cocaine use, and 31% reported sexual contact with prostitutes. Among incarcerated women, syphilis infection was frequent: of 113 women incarcerated for possession of illicit drugs in 1987-88, 7% were found to be infected with Treponema pallidum, and of 187 women incarcerated for prostitution in these years, 14% were infected.

From what I can read specific to Sweden and other Scandinavian countries is that you have some of the toughest drug laws in the EU, perhaps that is why there is not such a clear link, but there is a big link between prostitution and human traffiking there. I read that there is a big prostitution/drug link in Malmo, but no evidence to support it. The internet is crammed with data on this relationship, hundreds and hundreds of journals on it.

Maybe it’s different where you are, but afaik, in most countries the link between drug abuse and prostitution is very clear…

EDIT - I quickly found this document which has some stats on prostitution in the UK http://www.fawcettsociety.org.uk/index.asp?PageID=808

Some interesting links also between domestic abuse and prostitution.[/quote]Now, if you go down to the roots of this issue, what would your conclusion be? Mine would be that by putting a stigma on being a prostitute and segregating them from society is causing crime and other issues to rise.

If it was strictly controlled just like any other business there would be no problem. That will most likely not happen though, thanks to deeply rooted christian values. Contrary to popular belief and propaganda, not everyone is forced into prostitution. There’s plenty of people who enjoy their job and make a fuckload of cash doing it!
